maml:description.maml:para: Returns information about the SQL Database servers in the current subscription.

The Get-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet retrieves information about SQL Database servers in the current subscription. If a SQL Database server name is specified in the ServerName parameter, it returns an object with information about the specific SQL Database server. Else, it returns information about all the SQL Database servers.

The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database servers in the current subscription is returned.

The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database servers in the current subscription is returned.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns information about all of the SQL Database servers in the current subscription.
This command returns information about the “lpqd0zbr8y” server.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.

The Get-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet retrieves firewall rules from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription. If a firewall rule name is specified in the RuleName parameter, it returns information about the specific firewall rule. Else, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).
This command returns the specified firewall rule (“myRule”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet creates a new SQL Database server in the current subscription.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database server.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.

Administrator account password for your new SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Region or location where the new SQL Database server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database server.

Administrator account password for your new SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Region or location where the new SQL Database server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a SQL Database server.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.

The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet creates a new firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server. Any IP address within the range specified in the StartIpAddress and EndIpAddress parameters will be able to connect to the SQL Database server. A firewall rule with starting and ending IP addresses equal to 0.0.0.0 indicates that Windows Azure connections to this SQL Database server are allowed.
The name of the SQL Database server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
End value of the IP address range.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
End value of the IP address range.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
The name of the SQL Database server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new firewall rule (“myRule”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the specified SQL Database server from the current subscription.
The Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet removes the specified SQL Database server from the current subscription. It also deletes all databases under the specified SQL Database server.
The SQL Database server name to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The SQL Database server name to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a firewall rule from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule deletes a firewall rule from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The SQL Database server name from where the firewall rule is to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The SQL Database firewall rule name to be deleted.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The SQL Database firewall rule name to be deleted.
The SQL Database server name from where the firewall rule is to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes a firewall rule (“myRule”) from the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.

The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet updates the properties of the specified SQL Database server. In the current release, you can update only the administrator account password for a SQL Database server.
The name of the SQL Database server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.

The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The name of the SQL Database server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the administrator account password for the SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) with the new password (“myNewP@ssword”).

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of an existing firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server.
The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet updates the start IP address and end IP address values of an existing firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server.
Name of the SQL Database server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The new end IP address value.
Name of the SQL Database firewall rule to be updated.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
The new end IP address value.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Name of the SQL Database firewall rule to be updated.
Name of the SQL Database server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the start IP address and end IP address of the firewall rule (“myRule”) in the SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).
